basicdata.Description: A pathogenic fungus responsible for anthracnose disease in a wide range of fruit crops, vegetables, and ornamental plants. It causes necrotic lesions and fruit rot, leading to significant agricultural losses.

habitat: Commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions, affecting plant tissues such as leaves, stems, and fruits. It thrives in humid conditions and spreads via spores in water droplets.
importance: A major agricultural pathogen with economic importance due to its impact on fruit crops such as mango, avocado, papaya, and citrus. It is also used in plant pathology research to study fungal-plant interactions.

Pathogenicity Factors.Toxin Production: Produces host-specific toxins affecting different plant species.
Pathogenicity Factors.Effector Proteins: Employs effectors to manipulate host immunity and promote infection.
Pathogenicity Factors.Infection Strategy: Utilizes an appressorium to penetrate host tissues.

Host Range.Mango: Major cause of postharvest anthracnose in mangoes.
Host Range.Avocado: Leads to fruit rot and premature dropping.
Host Range.Papaya: Causes black spots on fruit surface.
Host Range.Citrus: Affects leaves and fruits, reducing yield.

otherNames.definition: A name sometimes used for banana-infecting strains of the fungus.
